title: WCAS INTL_ST 390-0-23 Special Topics in International Studies

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
For much of the world's population, land sustains livelihoods, shapes identities, and provides a source of
investment and security. Yet the centrality of land in everyday life also means that it can become a
source of contentious politics and violence. This class explores how struggles over access and rights to
land shape different forms of conflict and violence: between squatters and state officials, different
ethnic groups, or armed groups and the state.

The course explores questions of land and conflict in several parts. We begin by examining the question
of land meanings: what does land, property, and territory mean to different groups of people? How
does this help us understand why people organize or fight around issues of land? Second, the course
takes an historical and comparative view of the rules and institutions that shape people's rights and
access to land. The third part of the class explores theories that link land to conflict and violence. We
then apply these theories to explore a set of case studies of land-related conflict: from the recent armed
uprising in Oregon to civil war in Colombia. The last part of the class moves toward policy
considerations. How, for example, can a focus on land rights improve post-conflict resolution?
The course is interdisciplinary in its approach, drawing heavily on political science and political
geography. It should appeal to students interested in peace and conflict issues, environmental politics,
international development, and human rights.
